title: Fish Sinigang (Tilapia) - Filipino Sour Broth Dish Recipe
description: A very simple and quick Filipino dish. This is a sour broth soup with tilapia fish fillets. The flavor is sour but it actually enhances your appetite. This is considered comfort food in my house.

About Us The Allrecipes Allstars How to Add a Recipe GET THE MAGAZINE Recipes Soups, Stews and Chili Recipes Broth and Stock Recipes Fish Sinigang (Tilapia) - Filipino Sour Broth Dish 4.1 (31) 26 Reviews 5 Photos A very simple and quick Filipino dish. This is a sour broth soup with tilapia fish fillets. The flavor is sour but it actually enhances your appetite. This is considered comfort food in my house. Submitted by Meli D Updated on July 14, 2022 Save Rate Print Share Close Add Photo 5 5 5 Prep Time: 5 mins Cook Time: 10 mins Total Time: 15 mins Servings: 4 Yield: 4 servings Jump to Nutrition Facts Cook Mode (Keep screen awake) Ingredients 1x 2x 4x Oops! Something went wrong. Our team is working on it. Original recipe (1X) yields 4 servings ½ pound tilapia fillets, cut into chunks 1 small head bok choy, chopped 2 medium tomatoes, cut into chunks 1 cup thinly sliced daikon radish ¼ cup tamarind paste 3 cups water 2 dried red chile peppers (Optional) Directions In a medium pot, combine the tilapia, bok choy, tomatoes and radish. Stir together the tamarind paste and water; pour into the pot. Toss in the chili peppers if using. Bring to a boil, and cook for 5 minutes, or just until the fish is cooked through. Even frozen fish will cook in less than 10 minutes. Do not over cook or else the fish will fall apart. Ladle into bowls to serve. I Made It Print 50 home cooks made it! Nutrition Facts (per serving) 112 Calories 1g Fat 13g Carbs 13g Protein Show Full Nutrition Label Hide Full Nutrition Label Nutrition Facts Servings Per Recipe 4 Calories 112 % Daily Value * Total Fat 1g 1% Saturated Fat 0g 1% Cholesterol 21mg 7% Sodium 63mg 3% Total Carbohydrate 13g 5% Dietary Fiber 2g 8% Total Sugars 3g Protein 13g 26% Vitamin C 25mg 28% Calcium 64mg 5% Iron 1mg 5% Potassium 585mg 12% * Percent Daily Values are based on a 2,000 calorie diet. Your daily values may be higher or lower depending on your calorie needs. ** Nutrient information is not available for all ingredients. Amount is based on available nutrient data. (-) Information is not currently available for this nutrient. If you are following a medically restrictive diet, please consult your doctor or registered dietitian before preparing this recipe for personal consumption. Add Your Photo Photos of Fish Sinigang (Tilapia) - Filipino Sour Broth Dish 01 of 05 Photo by  Allrecipes Member 02 of 05 Photo by  KaliSIG 09/21/2020 03 of 05 Photo by  cooking mama 07/13/2020 I used vinegar and brown sugar and messed it up because I didn’t have tamarind. 04 of 05 Photo by  Nani 10/14/2008 This recipe is sooo simple yet, delicious. Very satisfying, especially since it's getting colder. I substitute the daikon with brown rice since I didn't have any on hand. Also, instead of the Tamarind paste, I used Worcestershire sauce, since I didn't have any of that either. I will surely make this again. 1 You’ll Also Love World's Greatest Vegetable Broth 138 Ratings Vegan and Gluten-Free Broth Powder 2 Ratings Ukha (Russian Fish Soup) 38 Ratings Bone Broth 23 Ratings Easy Lentil Soup 281 Ratings Butternut Squash Noodle Soup with Turkey 15 Ratings Rutabaga Stew 16 Ratings Broccoli Soup 396 Ratings Fresh Watermelon Gazpacho 3 Ratings LaWanna's Mango Salsa on Tilapia Fillets 11 Ratings Mongo Guisado (Mung Bean Soup) 42 Ratings Tortilla Soup I 91 Ratings Tilapia Ceviche 33 Ratings Split Pea and Ham Soup I 519 Ratings Chicken Gumbo Soup 30 Ratings Soup La Angelena 3 Ratings Allrecipes Newsletters Follow Us Dinners Meals Ingredients Occasions Cuisines Kitchen Tips News Features About Us Editorial Process Privacy Policy Product Vetting Terms of Service Advertise Careers Contact Your Privacy Choices   Allrecipes is part of the Dotdash Meredith publishing family. name: Meli D
instructions: In a medium pot, combine the tilapia, bok choy, tomatoes and radish. Stir together the tamarind paste and water; pour into the pot. Toss in the chili peppers if using. Bring to a boil, and cook for 5 minutes, or just until the fish is cooked through. Even frozen fish will cook in less than 10 minutes. Do not over cook or else the fish will fall apart. Ladle into bowls to serve.
